natural problem: The new Perry Hotter book will have a cover price of $\$25$. The local bookstore is offering two discounts $\$4.00$ off and $20\%$ off. A clever shopper realizes that the prices will be different depending on the order in which she claims her discounts. How much more money will she save by taking the better valued approach rather than the other approach? Express your answer in cents.
natural solution: If the clever shopper takes $4 off followed by $20\%$ off, the book will cost $0.8 \times (\$25 - \$4) = 0.8 \times \$21 = \$16.80$. If she takes $20\%$ off followed by $4 off, it will cost $(0.8 \times \$25) - \$4 = \$20 - \$4 = \$16.00$.
She will save $\$16.80 - 16.00 = \$0.80 = \boxed{80\text{ cents}}$ by taking the better-valued approach.

a_0.formal problem:
theorem
fixes cover_price dollar_discount percent_discount :: real
assumes h0 : "cover_price = 25"
and h1 : "dollar_discount = 4"
and h2 : "percent_discount = 0.20"
and h3 : "percent_discount * cover_price = percent_discount * (cover_price - dollar_discount)"
shows  "(cover_price - dollar_discount - percent_discount * (cover_price - dollar_discount)) - (cover_price - percent_discount * cover_price - dollar_discount) = 0.8"
a_0.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 The new Perry Hotter book will have a cover price of $\$25$. The local bookstore is offering two discounts $\$4.00$ off and $20\%$ off. A clever shopper realizes that the prices will be different depending on the order in which she claims her discounts. How much more money will she save by taking the better valued approach rather than the other approach? Express your answer in cents. The final Answer is 80\text{ cents}
 ### Proof
 If the clever shopper takes $4 off followed by $20\%$ off, the book will cost $0.8 \times (\$25 - \$4) = 0.8 \times \$21 = \$16.80$. If she takes $20\%$ off followed by $4 off, it will cost $(0.8 \times \$25) - \$4 = \$20 - \$4 = \$16.00$.
 She will save $\$16.80 - 16.00 = \$0.80 = \boxed{80\text{ cents}}$ by taking the better-valued approach.
 *)

theorem
fixes cover_price dollar_discount percent_discount :: real
assumes h0 : "cover_price = 25"
and h1 : "dollar_discount = 4"
and h2 : "percent_discount = 0.20"
and h3 : "percent_discount * cover_price = percent_discount * (cover_price - dollar_discount)"
shows  "(cover_price - dollar_discount - percent_discount * (cover_price - dollar_discount)) - (cover_price - percent_discount * cover_price - dollar_discount) = 0.8"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_0.informal problem: Given a book that has a cover price of $25. If you get a $4 discount off the cover price, and then also get a 20% discount off the new price, is this the same as getting the 20% discount off the original price and then getting the $4 discount? The final answer is yes.

a_1.formal problem:
theorem
fixes price :: real
assumes h0 : "price = 25"
and h1 : "real \<Rightarrow> real"
and h2 : "real \<Rightarrow> real"
and h3 : "\<forall>p. discount1 p = p - 4"
and h4 : "\<forall>p. discount2 p = p * 0.8"
shows  "abs(discount1 (discount2 price) - discount2 (discount1 price)) = 0.8"
a_1.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 The new Perry Hotter book will have a cover price of $\$25$. The local bookstore is offering two discounts $\$4.00$ off and $20\%$ off. A clever shopper realizes that the prices will be different depending on the order in which she claims her discounts. How much more money will she save by taking the better valued approach rather than the other approach? Express your answer in cents. The final Answer is 80\text{ cents}
 ### Proof
 If the clever shopper takes $4 off followed by $20\%$ off, the book will cost $0.8 \times (\$25 - \$4) = 0.8 \times \$21 = \$16.80$. If she takes $20\%$ off followed by $4 off, it will cost $(0.8 \times \$25) - \$4 = \$20 - \$4 = \$16.00$.
 She will save $\$16.80 - 16.00 = \$0.80 = \boxed{80\text{ cents}}$ by taking the better-valued approach.
 *)

theorem
fixes price :: real
assumes h0 : "price = 25"
and h1 : "real \<Rightarrow> real"
and h2 : "real \<Rightarrow> real"
and h3 : "\<forall>p. discount1 p = p - 4"
and h4 : "\<forall>p. discount2 p = p * 0.8"
shows  "abs(discount1 (discount2 price) - discount2 (discount1 price)) = 0.8"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_1.informal problem: Assume an item costs $25. There are two discounts available: discount1 reduces the price by $4 and discount2 reduces the price by 20%. Prove that the final price is the same whether you apply discount1 first and then discount2, or discount2 first and then discount1. The difference between the two final prices is $0.8.

a_2.formal problem:
theorem
fixes price :: real
assumes h0 : "price = 25"
shows  "abs ((price - 4) * 0.80 - price * 0.80 + 4) * 100 = 80"
a_2.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 The new Perry Hotter book will have a cover price of $\$25$. The local bookstore is offering two discounts $\$4.00$ off and $20\%$ off. A clever shopper realizes that the prices will be different depending on the order in which she claims her discounts. How much more money will she save by taking the better valued approach rather than the other approach? Express your answer in cents. The final Answer is 80\text{ cents}
 ### Proof
 If the clever shopper takes $4 off followed by $20\%$ off, the book will cost $0.8 \times (\$25 - \$4) = 0.8 \times \$21 = \$16.80$. If she takes $20\%$ off followed by $4 off, it will cost $(0.8 \times \$25) - \$4 = \$20 - \$4 = \$16.00$.
 She will save $\$16.80 - 16.00 = \$0.80 = \boxed{80\text{ cents}}$ by taking the better-valued approach.
 *)

theorem
fixes price :: real
assumes h0 : "price = 25"
shows  "abs ((price - 4) * 0.80 - price * 0.80 + 4) * 100 = 80"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_2.informal problem: Calculate the percentage change when the price of an item, originally priced at $25, is reduced by $4 and then an 80% discount is applied. The final answer is 80%.

a_3.formal problem:
theorem
fixes price :: real
assumes h0 : "price = 25"
and h1 : "real discount1 = 4"
and h2 : "real discount2 = 0.20"
and h3 : "real strategy1 = price - discount1 - (price - discount1) * discount2"
and h4 : "real strategy2 = price - price * discount2 - (price - price * discount2) - discount1"
shows  "100 * abs(strategy1 - strategy2) = 80"
a_3.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 The new Perry Hotter book will have a cover price of $\$25$. The local bookstore is offering two discounts $\$4.00$ off and $20\%$ off. A clever shopper realizes that the prices will be different depending on the order in which she claims her discounts. How much more money will she save by taking the better valued approach rather than the other approach? Express your answer in cents. The final Answer is 80\text{ cents}
 ### Proof
 If the clever shopper takes $4 off followed by $20\%$ off, the book will cost $0.8 \times (\$25 - \$4) = 0.8 \times \$21 = \$16.80$. If she takes $20\%$ off followed by $4 off, it will cost $(0.8 \times \$25) - \$4 = \$20 - \$4 = \$16.00$.
 She will save $\$16.80 - 16.00 = \$0.80 = \boxed{80\text{ cents}}$ by taking the better-valued approach.
 *)

theorem
fixes price :: real
assumes h0 : "price = 25"
and h1 : "real discount1 = 4"
and h2 : "real discount2 = 0.20"
and h3 : "real strategy1 = price - discount1 - (price - discount1) * discount2"
and h4 : "real strategy2 = price - price * discount2 - (price - price * discount2) - discount1"
shows  "100 * abs(strategy1 - strategy2) = 80"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_3.informal problem:
A product costs $25. There are two discount strategies being considered. 

The first strategy is to reduce the price by $4, then apply a 20% discount to the reduced price. 

The second strategy is to first apply a 20% discount to the original price, and then reduce the discounted price by $4. 

Calculate the absolute difference between the two strategies, and multiply by 100. The final answer is 80.

a_4.formal problem:
theorem
fixes cover_price discount_percent discount_fixed :: real
assumes h0 : "cover_price = 25"
and h1 : "discount_percent = 0.20"
and h2 : "discount_fixed = 4"
and h3 : "(cover_price - discount_fixed) * (1 - discount_percent) \<noteq> cover_price * (1 - discount_percent) - discount_fixed"
shows  "abs ((cover_price - discount_fixed) * (1 - discount_percent) - (cover_price * (1 - discount_percent) - discount_fixed)) = 0.80"
a_4.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 The new Perry Hotter book will have a cover price of $\$25$. The local bookstore is offering two discounts $\$4.00$ off and $20\%$ off. A clever shopper realizes that the prices will be different depending on the order in which she claims her discounts. How much more money will she save by taking the better valued approach rather than the other approach? Express your answer in cents. The final Answer is 80\text{ cents}
 ### Proof
 If the clever shopper takes $4 off followed by $20\%$ off, the book will cost $0.8 \times (\$25 - \$4) = 0.8 \times \$21 = \$16.80$. If she takes $20\%$ off followed by $4 off, it will cost $(0.8 \times \$25) - \$4 = \$20 - \$4 = \$16.00$.
 She will save $\$16.80 - 16.00 = \$0.80 = \boxed{80\text{ cents}}$ by taking the better-valued approach.
 *)

theorem
fixes cover_price discount_percent discount_fixed :: real
assumes h0 : "cover_price = 25"
and h1 : "discount_percent = 0.20"
and h2 : "discount_fixed = 4"
and h3 : "(cover_price - discount_fixed) * (1 - discount_percent) \<noteq> cover_price * (1 - discount_percent) - discount_fixed"
shows  "abs ((cover_price - discount_fixed) * (1 - discount_percent) - (cover_price * (1 - discount_percent) - discount_fixed)) = 0.80"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_4.informal problem: The cover price of a book is $25. There is a discount of 20% on the cover price. In addition to this, there is a fixed discount of $4. Find the absolute difference between the final price if the fixed discount is applied before the percentage discount and if the percentage discount is applied before the fixed discount. The final answer is $0.80.

a_5.formal problem:
theorem
fixes price :: real
assumes h0 : "price = 25"
and h1 : "\<forall>x. discount1 x = x - 4"
and h2 : "\<forall>x. discount2 x = 0.8 * x"
shows  "abs ((discount1 (discount2 price)) - (discount2 (discount1 price))) = 0.8"
a_5.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 The new Perry Hotter book will have a cover price of $\$25$. The local bookstore is offering two discounts $\$4.00$ off and $20\%$ off. A clever shopper realizes that the prices will be different depending on the order in which she claims her discounts. How much more money will she save by taking the better valued approach rather than the other approach? Express your answer in cents. The final Answer is 80\text{ cents}
 ### Proof
 If the clever shopper takes $4 off followed by $20\%$ off, the book will cost $0.8 \times (\$25 - \$4) = 0.8 \times \$21 = \$16.80$. If she takes $20\%$ off followed by $4 off, it will cost $(0.8 \times \$25) - \$4 = \$20 - \$4 = \$16.00$.
 She will save $\$16.80 - 16.00 = \$0.80 = \boxed{80\text{ cents}}$ by taking the better-valued approach.
 *)

theorem
fixes price :: real
assumes h0 : "price = 25"
and h1 : "\<forall>x. discount1 x = x - 4"
and h2 : "\<forall>x. discount2 x = 0.8 * x"
shows  "abs ((discount1 (discount2 price)) - (discount2 (discount1 price))) = 0.8"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_5.informal problem: A store offers two discounts on a $25 item: a $4 off coupon and a 20% off discount. What is the absolute difference between applying the $4 off coupon first followed by the 20% off discount and applying the 20% off discount first followed by the $4 off coupon? The final answer is $0.8.

a_6.formal problem:
theorem
fixes price :: real
assumes h0 : "price = 25"
and h1 : "4 :: real"
and h2 : "0.2 :: real"
and h3 : "price - discount1 - discount1 * discount2"
and h4 : "price * (1 - discount2) - discount1"
shows  "abs(approach2 - approach1) = 0.8"
a_6.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 The new Perry Hotter book will have a cover price of $\$25$. The local bookstore is offering two discounts $\$4.00$ off and $20\%$ off. A clever shopper realizes that the prices will be different depending on the order in which she claims her discounts. How much more money will she save by taking the better valued approach rather than the other approach? Express your answer in cents. The final Answer is 80\text{ cents}
 ### Proof
 If the clever shopper takes $4 off followed by $20\%$ off, the book will cost $0.8 \times (\$25 - \$4) = 0.8 \times \$21 = \$16.80$. If she takes $20\%$ off followed by $4 off, it will cost $(0.8 \times \$25) - \$4 = \$20 - \$4 = \$16.00$.
 She will save $\$16.80 - 16.00 = \$0.80 = \boxed{80\text{ cents}}$ by taking the better-valued approach.
 *)

theorem
fixes price :: real
assumes h0 : "price = 25"
and h1 : "4 :: real"
and h2 : "0.2 :: real"
and h3 : "price - discount1 - discount1 * discount2"
and h4 : "price * (1 - discount2) - discount1"
shows  "abs(approach2 - approach1) = 0.8"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_6.informal problem:
A product has an original price of $25$. There are two discount approaches applied to the product:

1. Approach 1: Apply a discount of $4 (discount1)$, and then apply a 20% discount (0.2 or $discount2$) to the remaining amount.
2. Approach 2: Apply a 20% discount first, and then subtract the $4$ discount.

Find the absolute difference between the final prices of the product using Approach 1 and Approach 2. The final answer is $0.8$.

a_7.formal problem:
theorem
fixes cover_price discount1 discount2 better_approach other_approach :: real
assumes h0 : "cover_price = 25"
and h1 : "discount1 = 4"
and h2 : "discount2 = 0.20"
and h3 : "better_approach = min (cover_price - discount1) * (1 - discount2) (cover_price * (1 - discount2) - discount1)"
and h4 : "other_approach = max (cover_price - discount1) * (1 - discount2) (cover_price * (1 - discount2) - discount1)"
shows  "100 * (other_approach - better_approach) = 80"
a_7.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 The new Perry Hotter book will have a cover price of $\$25$. The local bookstore is offering two discounts $\$4.00$ off and $20\%$ off. A clever shopper realizes that the prices will be different depending on the order in which she claims her discounts. How much more money will she save by taking the better valued approach rather than the other approach? Express your answer in cents. The final Answer is 80\text{ cents}
 ### Proof
 If the clever shopper takes $4 off followed by $20\%$ off, the book will cost $0.8 \times (\$25 - \$4) = 0.8 \times \$21 = \$16.80$. If she takes $20\%$ off followed by $4 off, it will cost $(0.8 \times \$25) - \$4 = \$20 - \$4 = \$16.00$.
 She will save $\$16.80 - 16.00 = \$0.80 = \boxed{80\text{ cents}}$ by taking the better-valued approach.
 *)

theorem
fixes cover_price discount1 discount2 better_approach other_approach :: real
assumes h0 : "cover_price = 25"
and h1 : "discount1 = 4"
and h2 : "discount2 = 0.20"
and h3 : "better_approach = min (cover_price - discount1) * (1 - discount2) (cover_price * (1 - discount2) - discount1)"
and h4 : "other_approach = max (cover_price - discount1) * (1 - discount2) (cover_price * (1 - discount2) - discount1)"
shows  "100 * (other_approach - better_approach) = 80"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_7.informal problem: A book has a cover price of $25. There are two discounts available: a $4 flat discount or a 20% percentage discount. You can choose one of two approaches to apply the discounts: (1) apply the flat discount first, then the percentage discount or (2) apply the percentage discount first, then the flat discount. Find the difference in the final prices between the approach with the higher cost and the approach with the lower cost. Multiply the result by 100. The final answer is 80.

a_8.formal problem:
theorem
fixes price :: real
assumes h0 : "price = 25"
and h1 : "discount1 = 4"
and h2 : "discount2 = 0.20"
shows  "better_savings = 80 / 100"
a_8.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 The new Perry Hotter book will have a cover price of $\$25$. The local bookstore is offering two discounts $\$4.00$ off and $20\%$ off. A clever shopper realizes that the prices will be different depending on the order in which she claims her discounts.  She will save $\$16.80 - 16.00 = \$0.80 = \boxed{80\text{ cents}}$ by taking the better-valued approach.
 *)

theorem
fixes price :: real
assumes h0 : "price = 25"
and h1 : "discount1 = 4"
and h2 : "discount2 = 0.20"
shows  "better_savings = 80 / 100"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_8.informal problem: A product has a regular price of $25. There are two available discounts: a $4 flat discount and a 20% discount. What is the better savings in terms of the percentage? The final answer is 80%.

a_9.formal problem:
theorem
fixes book_price discount_1 discount_2 :: real
assumes h0 : "book_price = 25"
and h1 : "discount_1 = 4"
and h2 : "discount_2 = 0.20"
shows  "(book_price - discount_1) * (1 - discount_2) - (book_price * (1 - discount_2) - discount_1) = 0.8"
a_9.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 The new Perry Hotter book will have a cover price of $\$25$. The local bookstore is offering two discounts $\$4.00$ off and $20\%$ off. A clever shopper realizes that the prices will be different depending on the order in which she claims her discounts. How much more money will she save by taking the better valued approach rather than the other approach? Express your answer in cents. The final Answer is 80\text{ cents}
 ### Proof

 She will save $\$16.80 - 16.00 = \$0.80 = \boxed{80\text{ cents}}$ by taking the better-valued approach.
 *)

theorem
fixes book_price discount_1 discount_2 :: real

a_9.informal problem: A book costs $25. There are two discounts available: a $4 discount or a 20% discount. Calculate the difference between applying the $4 discount first and then the 20% discount, and applying the 20% discount first and then the $4 discount. The final answer is $0.8.
